metadata.title: Mexico Rejects DEA 'Project Portero' Claim as US Embassy Says Cooperation Exists

left: Mexico has stated that there is no agreement with the DEA for new border enforcement collaboration, according to an official source.
Claudia Sheinbaum clarified that the only event mentioned was a workshop in Texas attended by four members of Mexico's police force.
Sheinbaum indicated that any official announcements will come from her administration, not individual agencies.
Sheinbaum requested the DEA to respect Mexico and follow agreed-upon protocols for announcements.
center: Mexico has stated that there is no agreement with the DEA for new border enforcement collaboration, according to an official source.
Claudia Sheinbaum clarified that the only event mentioned was a workshop in Texas attended by four members of Mexico's police force.
Sheinbaum indicated that any official announcements will come from her administration, not individual agencies.
Sheinbaum requested the DEA to respect Mexico and follow agreed-upon protocols for announcements.
right: Mexico's President Claudia Sheinbaum stated that her government does not have an agreement with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration regarding Project Portero.
Sheinbaum emphasized during a press conference, 'There is no agreement with the DEA.'
The DEA described Project Portero as a major initiative to combat cartels, but Sheinbaum clarified that there is no agreement with the DEA.
Sheinbaum urged the DEA to respect Mexico's protocols, asserting that agreements are signed with the U.S. government, not individual agencies.
